Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Chemical safety is an important part of Michael Lewis operations. Michael Lewis recently conducted an audit of their Process Safety Management Program / Risk Management Plan and has dutifully implemented the recommendations from that audit. Continuous improvement in safety is an important goal for Michael Lewis. 

XI.	Management Program
Michael Lewis has developed a management system to oversee the implementation of the risk management program elements.  This includes assigning a qualified person (or position) to have overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the risk management program elements.  If any portion of the program is delegated to others, the names or positions of those individuals are to be documented, and the lines of authority defined through an organization chart or similar document.  Shelly Rosen, Owner, is responsible for overall implementation of the Risk Management Program, while Ron Feehan, Facilities Manager is the Emergency Contact and has responsibilities related to the daily upkeep of the PSM / RMP.

aximize the safety of all employees, contractors, and visitors in the event of an emergency and also guard against environmental consequences.
 
III.	Facility Identification
The Michael Lewis facility is located at 8900 West 50th Street in McCook, Illinois. The facility stores and distributes grocery and related merchant products. The NAICS code for the processes at the facility is 42449.  Many areas of the warehouse are refrigerated to maintain temperature in the storage areas.

Michael Lewis is a warehouse and distribution facility that runs a continuous operation. Michael Lewis utilizes a regulated substance, anhydrous ammonia, for refrigeration. One closed loop refrigeration system is utilized to maintain temperature in the freezer, dock, and cooler. Michael Lewis has a total of 13,029 pounds (13,000 pounds rounded to two significant figures) of Anhydrous Ammonia onsite. 

An aerial photo identifying the site location is included as Appendix A.

IV.	Hazard Assessment  Worst Case Scenario (WCS)
Appendix B consists of the RMP*Submit Printout and contains additional information on the worst-case scenario.  Appendix C consists of the offsite consequence analysis data and maps for the worst-case release scenario.

Appendix B consists of the RMP*Submit Printout and contains additional information on the alternate scenario.  Appendix D consists of the offsite consequence analysis data and maps for the alternative release scenario.

VI.	General Accidental Release Prevention Program
A prevention program is in place to minimize the risk of hazardous chemical releases in accordance with the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and the EPA Risk Management Program.   However, as discussed throughout this document Michael Lewis is continuously improving this program. 

This prevention program covers those processes that handle ammonia above the threshold quantity for both PSM and RMP rules.

The most recent audit of the PSM program was conducted on July 27, 2023, and the next audit will occur before July 27, 2026, in compliance with the requirement to conduct PSM audits every three years.  The elements of the PSM / Program 3 prevention program and a brief description are listed below.
 

	Employee Participation  Michael Lewis has developed a site-specific employee participation plan that ensures employees, and their representatives are consulted when conducting and developing process hazard analyses and other information required to be developed under the PSM/RMP regulation.  In addition, the employee participation program will ensure employees, and their representatives have access to process hazard analyses and all other information required to be developed under PSM/RMP.
	Process Safety Information  Michael Lewis maintains a site-specific PSI program that ensures information pertaining to the hazards, technology, and equipment of the process are properly developed and maintained.
	Process Hazard Analysis  Michael Lewis has developed a site-specific PHA program that ensures a PHA is conducted initially, at a minimum of every five (5) years, and whenever a change is significant enough to require a change in PSI.  In addition, this program ensures PHAs are conducted in accordance with OSHA and EPA regulations and ensures findings and recommendations of PHAs are properly documented. Michael Lewis completed a thorough PHA revalidation study for the ammonia refrigeration systems on January 10, 2024.
	Operating Procedures  Michael Lewis has updated a site-specific procedure that ensures operating procedures provide clear instruction for different phases of process operations and ensures they are properly maintained.  
	Training  Michael Lewis has developed a site-specific training procedure that ensures employees operating the ammonia process have the knowledge to safely operate the process, are aware of the potential hazards of the process, and

understand the causes of process problems.
	Management of Change  Michael Lewis has developed a site-specific management of change procedure that ensures changes (except for replacement in kind) to the ammonia process, such as additions of new equipment or changes in operating, maintenance, or other procedures are documented. 
	Pre-Startup Review  Michael Lewis has developed a site-specific pre-startup safety review procedure that ensures a safety review is performed when modifications to the ammonia process are significant enough to require a change in PSI.
	Mechanical Integrity  Michael Lewis has updated a site-specific mechanical integrity procedure that ensures written preventative maintenance procedures are developed and maintained, preventative maintenance tests and inspections are properly documented, and employees maintaining the process receive adequate training.
 
	Contractor Qualifications  Michael Lewis has developed a site-specific contractor qualification procedure that ensures all contract employers safety performance and programs are evaluated, a contract employee injury and illness log is maintained, information of potential hazards are communicated between Michael Lewis and the contract employer, and required training and information is communicated, such as the provisions of the emergency action plan and control over entrance into process areas.
	Incident Investigation  Michael Lewis has developed a site-specific incident investigation procedure that ensures each incident that either results in a release or could have resulted in a release of anhydrous ammonia is investigated, within 48 hours, by a team of at least one person knowledgeable in the process.  This procedure will also make provisions to ensure a report is prepared at the conclusion of the investigation and findings are promptly addressed. 
	Compliance Audit  Michael Lewis has developed a site-specific compliance audit program that ensures compliance audits are conducted a

t a minimum of every three years to verify that Michael Lewis PSM/RMP practices and procedures are adequate and are being followed.  The most recent compliance audit was completed July 27, 2023.
	Hot Work Permits  Michael Lewis has developed a best management practice for hot work and hot work permits.

VII.	Five-Year Accident History
The Michael Lewis facility has not had an accidental anhydrous ammonia release, which resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage in the last five years.

VIII.	Emergency Action Program
Michael Lewis has developed an emergency action plan to ensure that in the event of an emergency the facility personnel are aware of the appropriate actions to take and authorities to contact in order to mitigate the effects of a release.  

Michael Lewis has communicated and trained facility employees on proper evacuation procedures and has had interaction with the McCook and LaGrange Fire Departments. In addition, the facility has coordinated their emergency action plan with the Suburban Cook County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).   

Although Michael Lewis does not have an onsite hazardous materials response team, selected individuals have received HAZWOPER training through classroom instruction, on-the-job training, and drills.  The current HAZWOPER training includes the first responder awareness level, the first responder operations level, and hazardous materials technician training.  

The facility has windsocks present onsite for use in determining wind direction in the event of an ammonia release and evacuation of the building.

The current Safety Data Sheet (SDS) for anhydrous ammonia is included in Appendix E. 

IX.	Emergency Communications
The telephone numbers of agencies and plant personnel that may be contacted in case of an emergency are included in the facilitys Emergency Action Plan.
